othermeta.content: Step-by-step operational procedure to detect, contain, investigate and restore OT systems following a cyber incident in glass-manufacturing plants.

fig.title: Figure 1: Forming Machine Cyberattack Flow Chart

ol.li:
In preparation for a potential cyberattack, follow these steps:
For the Machine Server
Verify that the machine server backups are occurring, using document FES-03-117 Machine Server Backups for guidance (see Section 4 for references to associated Forming Electronic Work Instructions).
If the machine server backup is not activated, contact your Forming Electronics (FES) DNL
Ensure the backup on other Forming Manufacturing Computers are being done properly.

The following situations may be warning signs of a potential cyberattack:
It is not possible to log into the control system, either at the equipment, in the plant, or remotely.
This inability to log into the control system has to happen for several users trying to log into any one type of Forming System (i.e. Machine Servers, Forming Supervisory Computer, PIC/PRS, LineServer, FlexIS, UC, XPAR, Gob Weight Control systems, etc.)
The login control system screen is absent even after a reboot; instead there are several tasks running in the background without the ability to stop them.
Users are able to log into the control system but are not able to perform any control actions, even when using the correct login credentials.
In this case, the control system screens will appear to be frozen to any user input.
Users are able to log into the control system but, although the network cable is connected, they are experiencing one or more of the following problems:
Inability to find data that was previously in the database
Unexpected pop-up windows are shown
Server is running slowly
Missing storage space
Missing files
Unusual crashes or error messages
Excessive network activity and/or slower-than-normal network response

If you experience any of these problems, perform the following steps:
Open an incident with the I.T. Global Service Desk to inform them of the ongoing situation, and request that Information Security verify if the system is actually being compromised by a cyberattack.
Make sure to define the I.T. incident: “Cybersecurity Incident” and mark it as a “High Priority”, stating which lines and machines are being affected due to the ongoing issue.

Communicate to the Immediate Supervisor and the Plant Engineer that the cyberattack has been reported and is under review.
The Plant Engineer shall inform the Plant Manager, Unit Plant Managers (UPMs), Line Leader, and Job Change Coordinator for the plant.
Ensure that the incident is reported to Discipline Network Leaders (DNLs) of Forming, IS Machine Maintenance, and Job Change.

In general, Space recommends that the response follow the priorities listed below:
Protect personnel and assets – ensure that all employees are safe, and are not executing activities that could put themselves or others at risk.
Wait for instruction from I.T. for next steps.
Be prepared to follow your plant emergency protocol instructions, if deemed necessary.

After receiving the incident notification, Information Security will analyze the situation and assign an initial severity classification in accordance with the SIRP (Security Incident Response Plan) which activates the Space Cyber Crisis Management Plan.
Further instructions from the Operations Technology Lead will follow.
If the cyberattack is confirmed, the Space Cyber Crisis Management Plan will be activated
